titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Walking this morning under the trees, met Mr: Kinnaird, who join’d me, and went into the park. Call’d with him at Metra’s the bookseller’s— Evening at Princess Henry’s— Play’d chess with Mr: Garlike. Afterwards at Dr: Brown’s, where Mrs: A. spent the evening— The youngest Mr: Headlam there.
2. Mrs: A— very ill all night, and all this day with an head-ache— I spent the evening at Prince Ferdinand’s. Play’d Whist with Madame de Bredow, Madame de Grappendorf, and Countess Redern.

3. Mrs: A. very ill, all night again, and continued unwell the whole day— Mrs: Brown and her daughters spent the evening with us— The Doctor came for a couple of hours— Play’d chess with him. Met Lord Carysfort this forenoon— He walk’d with me into the park.

4. Mrs: A. continues unwell— But went however to the ball at the Minister Alvensleben’s— We stay’d there not more than half an hour— Pass’d the remainder of the evening at Dr: Brown’s— Play’d a game of chess with him.— Saw for the first time Sotheby’s translation of Oberon.

5. We were engaged to spend this evening at Mr: Schickler’s, but Mrs: A— was so ill that we were obliged to send an excuse— We stay’d at home.— It is impossible it should end well—however hope may delude.

6. Mr: Maclure called to take leave; he is going to France— Mrs: A— was bled this morning; but it will do no good. Dr: Brown called in the forenoon and again in the evening— Finished reading the Duke of Nivernois’s Richardet— Upon the whole I think not very highly of it.

7. Mrs: A. continued unwell the greater part of the day. But was better in the evening. I received at length from Mr: Arbuthnot Sotheby’s Oberon, and his Georgics— Read part of the first this evening, and compared it with Dryden’s translation— Mr: Sotheby’s preface is not remarkable for diffidence; but his performance is such as justifies the consciousness of powers which he shows. The two Mr: Headlam’s called and took leave.
8. Continued reading the two translations of the Georgics. Spent the evening at Lord Carysfort’s; the company there, considerably numerous. Play’d chess with Mr: Garlike.
9. Countess Pauline Neale paid a visit to Mrs: A— Mrs: Brown and her daughters, and Mr: Proby spent the evening with us. Cold weather— Ground for the first time this season covered with snow.

10. Finished reading the two translations of the first Georgic.— Still working upon my own of Oberon. Spent the Evening at Dr: Brown’s.— Mrs: St. George there— Play’d chess with the Doctor. Mr: Fagel called this morning upon me— He lodges in the house.
11. Usual walk in the park— Evening at Count Alvensleben’s ball— Play’d chess with Mr: Garlike. Reading the second book of the Georgics with the two translations.

12. Doctor Brown call’d before dinner— Went for half an hour to Baron Heinitz’s— Spent the remainder of the evening at Prince Ferdinand’s— Play’d whist with Madam de Grappendorf, General Tempelhoff, and Mr: de Sydow.

13. First part of the evening at the ball of the Baron de Schroetter— The company, between four and five hundred persons— Remainder of the Eve at Mr: Cohen’s, where we supp’d— Play’d whist with him, Dr: Brown and Mr: Richard.
14. Dr. Brown’s family, Mrs: Hunter and Miss Jones, Mr: Garlike, Mr: Kinnaird and Mr: Ridley pass’d the evening with us.— Play’d chess with Garlike.

15. Evening at Mrs: St: George’s where she had a little ball— I danced with her, and afterwards play’d chess with Dr: Brown and Mr: Garlike— Conversation with Mr: Gentz.— I came home very hoarse— Find myself continually getting bad colds— We came home late.
16. Confined myself the whole day to the house, on account of my cold. Wrote a little— Could not read aloud to Mrs: A— Read therefore the first volume of Godwin’s St: Leon.
17. Again confined all day to the house with my cold— But Mrs: Adams was seized with one of her sudden and violent illnesses, just after dinner.— Exactly such as she had yesterday was a twelve-month.

18. Mrs: A— somewhat better, though still very weak after her illness— I walk’d out in the forenoon. In the evening, went for about an hour to Mr: Alvensleben’s ball.— On returning home, had a letter from my brother. Weather very cold
19. Mrs: A— again very ill this forenoon; but rather better towards night. Margaret Brown called, and pass’d half an hour with her.— Read but little this day.
20. Mrs: A— rather better— The weather which has been very cold is growing mild again— The three Miss Brown’s took tea, and pass’d the Evening with us.— Read about half the fourth Georgic.

21. The king and queen came to town for the winter— I pass’d the Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s— Play’d whist, with Count Neale, Mr: Konatowsky, and Helbig— Call’d afterwards at Dr: Brown’s, to take up Mrs: A— who had pass’d the evening there.— Finish’d reading the Georgics, with Dryden’s & Sotheby’s translations. The last is much superior throughout, to the other.— I had never before read the original with so much attention.

22. Lord Carysfort and Mr: Garlike called to pay us a visit this afternoon— Read in the evening the first book of Dryden’s Æneid— It is much better done than his Georgics; but the subject was much less difficult— I am likewise busied in writing letters to my brother, and in correcting my translation of Oberon.

23. Paid with Mrs: A. the customary visit of ceremony to Countess Voss— Mrs: A. then went and pass’d the Evening with Mrs: St: George— I called for an hour at Genl: O’Farrill’s, and afterwards, went to Mr: Schickler’s— Play’d whist with the two young Krudener’s and another Russian officer— Did not stay to supper.

24. Mr: Vignon, the first Secretary of the french legation called upon me this forenoon.— Took but a short walk— Read to Mrs: A— the second book of Dryden’s Æneid, and to myself part of the dedication to the Marquis of Normanby— Dryden’s prose style is much celebrated, but he writes in a manner too desultory to suit my taste.

25. Christmas day. Dined and spent the evening at Lord Carysfort’s, with all the English company now here. We danced untill eleven o’clock— In the evening the company became more numerous. We came away exactly at midnight.
26. Dined at General O’Farrill’s, with a small party of Gentlemen only. Spent the Evening at home and read to Mrs: A— a book of the Æneid.
27. Continue writing to my brother, but very slowly— Spent the evening at home again, and read a book of the Æneid. Weather moderate but very indifferent.

28. The first Court after the return of the king and queen to town, was held this Evening. Mrs: A. went with me.— The heat and the crowd were both excessive— Many Russian presentations much caressed, and many english ones much slighted.— We came home at nine.

29. Mrs: A— very unwell all day— We dined at Mrs: Brown’s, with English company— The Doctor was obliged to go to Potsdam and did not dine at home.— We likewise spent the Evening there— Had music and singing— Play’d chess with Lord Carysfort, and Mr: Kinnaird.
30. Mrs: A— somewhat better— We pass’d the evening again at Dr: Brown’s— Miss Bischofwerder was there— Finished the second volume of St: Leon.

31. At the close of the year and of the century, the Swedish Minister, gave a splendid ball, and his intention was that the transition to the new century should be marked with merriment and joy.— My wife (praised be God!) after some hesitation whether she would go or not, thought it would be best for her to pass the evening at Lady Carysfort’s and Mrs: Brown’s— I went to make her excuse— I play’d cards. The ball began after eight o’clock— Soon after nine, young Dorville, a lieutenant in the infantry, after leading down a dance, just as he got to the bottom fell instantly dead, without a gasp or a groan— It was at first supposed he had only fainted; a surgeon and physician were called in, and every expedient possible was used to bring him to life, in vain— I came away before it was fully ascertained that he was dead, in order to prevent the story’s coming too abruptly to my wife— Found her at Mrs: Brown’s— Soon after I left Mr: Engeström’s house, and when the fact that the youth was certainly dead had become unquestionable, the scene that ensued was dreadful— Faintings, hysteric fits, convulsions, and raving madness, mark’d the shock of this calamitous accident, upon the minds of many ladies who were present. The party was broken up, and Mrs: Engeström, in the wildest delirium, carried away to Mrs: O’Farril’s, where she pass’d the night.— The opinion of the professional men called in was, that his death was owing to the excessive tightness of his clothes, and perhaps to his having drank several glasses of cold limonade, while heated with dancing.

The sentiments of devotion which naturally recur to me at the close of every year, must of course be yet stronger than usual, at a period which can not happen to me again— They were rendered still more solemn by this awful admonition of the vanity and frailty of earthly enjoyments. I pass’d the period of transition between the two centuries in communion with my own soul, and in prostration to the being who directs the universe; with thanksgiving for his numerous blessings, in the past time, and with prayer for a mind to bear whatever the future dispensations of his Providence may be, in such a manner as may be most conformable to his will.
